overview.title: What are Common Nouns?
overview.description: Common nouns are general names for people, places, animals, things, or ideas. They are not specific names and are usually written in lowercase. Understanding common nouns helps learners identify general objects and concepts in everyday language.
key_points: Name general people, places, animals, things, or ideas
Are not capitalized unless at the start of sentences
Used to refer to a class or group rather than specific entities
Often preceded by articles like 'a', 'an', or 'the'
overview.importance: Knowing common nouns enables clear communication about everyday objects and concepts without needing to be specific.

sections.title: Definition and Characteristics
sections.content: Common nouns are words that name general items rather than specific ones. They refer to any person, place, animal, thing, or idea and are not capitalized unless they start a sentence or form part of a title.

subsections.subtitle: General vs Specific
subsections.text: Common nouns contrast with proper nouns which name specific entities. For example, 'city' is a common noun while 'New York' is a proper noun.

sections.title: Usage in Sentences
sections.content: Common nouns are used with articles and can be singular or plural. They form the subject or object in sentences and help describe general things or people.

subsections.subtitle: Articles with Common Nouns
subsections.text: Singular common nouns typically require an article such as 'a' or 'an' when mentioned for the first time.

subsections.subtitle: Plural Forms
subsections.text: Common nouns usually have plural forms created by adding 's' or 'es'. Some plural forms may be irregular.

sections.title: Importance in Language Learning
sections.content: Mastering common nouns is essential for reading, writing, and speaking about everyday things. It provides a foundation for identifying objects and ideas in both spoken and written communication.

subsections.subtitle: Real-World Application
subsections.text: Using common nouns correctly helps learners describe their environment, talk about people, places, and things around them with clarity.
examples: I saw a dog in the park.

grammar_rules.title: Lowercase Writing
grammar_rules.description: Common nouns are written in lowercase unless they begin a sentence or appear in titles.
grammar_rules.tip: Remember common nouns are not capitalized like proper nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Use of Articles
grammar_rules.description: Singular common nouns usually require an article ('a', 'an', 'the') to specify definiteness or indefiniteness.
grammar_rules.tip: Check if the noun is singular ‚Äî add 'a' or 'an' unless it's definite with 'the'.

grammar_rules.title: Plural Forms
grammar_rules.description: To express more than one, most common nouns form plurals by adding 's' or 'es'; some have irregular plurals.
correct_examples: Three books are on the table.
incorrect_examples: Three book are on the table.
grammar_rules.tip: Learn common irregular plurals like child ‚Üí children.

grammar_rules.title: Concrete vs Abstract
grammar_rules.description: Common nouns can be concrete (things you can sense) or abstract (ideas, emotions). Clarify usage accordingly.
grammar_rules.tip: Associate concrete nouns with physical things, abstract nouns with ideas.

grammar_rules.title: Common noun modifiers
grammar_rules.description: Common nouns often appear with adjectives or determiners that describe or specify them.
grammar_rules.tip: Adjectives come before common nouns to describe them.

examples.sentence: The teacher is preparing a lesson.
examples.analysis: The common noun 'teacher' refers to any person who teaches.

examples.sentence: A doctor helps sick people.
examples.analysis: 'Doctor' is a general name for a profession.

examples.sentence: She is a student at the university.

examples.sentence: The waiter served our food.
examples.analysis: 'Waiter' refers to any person serving food.

examples.sentence: Parents want the best for their children.
examples.analysis: 'Parents' and 'children' are common nouns referring to family roles.

examples.sentence: The city is crowded today.

examples.sentence: We went to a restaurant for dinner.
examples.analysis: 'Restaurant' is a common noun for a dining place.

examples.sentence: The park was full of people.
examples.analysis: 'Park' names a general outdoor public space.

examples.sentence: She traveled across the country.
examples.analysis: 'Country' is a general noun, not naming any specific one.

examples.sentence: The beach was sunny and warm.
examples.analysis: 'Beach' indicates a general seaside area.

examples.sentence: A dog barked loudly.
examples.analysis: 'Dog' denotes any member of that animal species.

examples.sentence: The cat is sleeping on the couch.
examples.analysis: 'Cat' is used generally for the animal.

examples.sentence: Birds are singing in the trees.
examples.analysis: 'Birds' is the plural of the common noun 'bird'.

examples.sentence: She has a pet rabbit.
examples.analysis: 'Rabbit' is a general noun for the animal.

examples.sentence: Fishes swim in the aquarium.
examples.analysis: 'Fishes' is plural for more than one fish.

examples.sentence: I bought a new book yesterday.
examples.analysis: 'Book' is a general noun naming an object.

examples.sentence: The table is made of wood.
examples.analysis: 'Table' refers to any flat-topped piece of furniture.

complex_sentences.sentence: The teacher assigned the students a project about the city's history.
complex_sentences.analysis: Common nouns 'teacher', 'students', 'project', and 'city' are used to describe general roles and places.

complex_sentences.sentence: A dog chased the cat across the park and through the garden.
complex_sentences.analysis: Common nouns 'dog', 'cat', 'park', and 'garden' illustrate general animals and places.

complex_sentences.sentence: Many books were stacked on the old wooden table in the classroom.
complex_sentences.analysis: Common nouns 'books', 'table', and 'classroom' describe objects and locations.

common_mistakes.wrong: I saw a Dog in the garden.
common_mistakes.correct: I saw a dog in the garden.
common_mistakes.explanation: Common nouns should not be capitalized unless at sentence start.
common_mistakes.tip: Only capitalize common nouns if they begin a sentence.

common_mistakes.wrong: She bought book from the store.
common_mistakes.correct: She bought a book from the store.
common_mistakes.explanation: Singular common nouns need an article for clarity.
common_mistakes.tip: Always use 'a' or 'an' with singular common nouns.

common_mistakes.wrong: There are many childs in the park.
common_mistakes.correct: There are many children in the park.
common_mistakes.explanation: Child is irregular; plural is 'children', not 'childs'.

common_mistakes.wrong: She visited New city last summer.
common_mistakes.correct: She visited the city last summer.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use common noun for general places unless naming specific ones.
common_mistakes.tip: Distinguish if noun should be specific (proper) or general (common).

common_mistakes.explanation: Adjectives have a specific order before common nouns.

common_mistakes.wrong: She has a books in her bag.
common_mistakes.correct: She has books in her bag.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use articles appropriately; 'a' is not used with plurals.
common_mistakes.tip: Do not use 'a' before plural nouns.

common_mistakes.wrong: Much books are on the shelf.
common_mistakes.correct: Many books are on the shelf.
common_mistakes.tip: Use 'many' with countable nouns, 'much' with uncountable.

common_mistakes.explanation: Add apostrophe + s for singular possessive.

identification.title: Identify the Common Nouns
identification.instructions: Read each sentence and underline the common nouns.

questions.sentence: The cat is chasing a mouse.
questions.explanation: 'Cat' and 'mouse' are common nouns as they name general animals.

questions.sentence: She bought a new dress from the store.
questions.explanation: 'Dress' and 'store' are common nouns naming general things and places.

questions.sentence: The teacher gave homework to the students.
questions.explanation: All three are common nouns referring to general people and things.

questions.sentence: The flowers in the garden are blooming.
questions.explanation: 'Flowers' and 'garden' are common nouns naming plants and places.

questions.sentence: Books are available in the library.
questions.explanation: 'Books' and 'library' are common nouns naming objects and places.

correction.title: Correct the Errors in Common Nouns
correction.instructions: Read the sentences and correct the errors related to common nouns.

questions.sentence: I saw A Dog on the street.
answer: I saw a dog on the street.

questions.sentence: He bought apple from the market.
answer: He bought an apple from the market.
questions.explanation: Use 'an' before words starting with vowel sounds.

questions.sentence: They visited A museum last week.
answer: They visited a museum last week.

fun_facts: Common nouns can be concrete or abstract.
Not every common noun has a proper noun equivalent.
The plural form of 'child' is 'children', an irregular plural.
Common nouns are the most frequently used nouns in English.
Proper nouns always begin with a capital letter, while common nouns do not.
Animals, objects, and places are often referred to by common nouns.
Some words can be both common and proper nouns depending on usage.
Common nouns are essential for basic communication in any language.
Every language has its own version of common nouns for general objects.
Common nouns can act as subjects, objects, or complements in sentences.
